review_title: Please look for a job elsewhere
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The faculty and low-level staff are some of the kindest, hardest working people I have ever met. They are all undercompensated and undervalued, but work hard nevertheless. The mismanagement does occasionally offer opportunities to learn new skills.
cons:
The CEO and President of the university are a married couple who are ill-equipped to run an institution of higher learning. In 2013, they paid themselves $1.5 and $1.6 million in salaries (per the school's not-for-profit tax disclosures). The same year, they also paid themselves more than half a million dollars each in bonuses. Meanwhile, staff are only given a Christmas party each year and are not offered Christmas or performance bonuses.

Many heads of departments have been working at AMDA for years without proper job qualifications. Few have worked in higher education before and some do not hold even a Bachelor's degree. Their lack of understanding of how to efficiently operate an academic institution trickles down into every facet. Departments are understaffed, underpaid, and crammed into office spaces that are way over capacity.

Tuition is also sky high, but the money is not used to adequately support students or faculty. Only a handful of faculty have offices and administrative support is practically non-existent. There are no tenure track positions and faculty are sometimes not rehired without explanation. Some are hired last minute (even after classes have begun) and are assigned classes they're not qualified to teach. Understandably, faculty rarely stay for very long.

The frustration, lately teetering on outrage, is palpable among staff on both campuses. These are the warnings I wish I had been given. Please look elsewhere for employment.

job_title: Marketing Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Friendly co-workers; Flexible hours; Decent pay/benefits.
cons:
SCAMDA

I was hired by AMDA for a marketing position, a high-level one, basically the number two position. Initially, they bent over backward to make me feel welcome: my own office, brand new amenities, everyone stopping in to say hello, etc. I thought I’d won the lottery, as the salary and benefits were quite solid, as well. 

Then, cracks started to show on the surface. The entire organization runs around the mercurial personality of the head of the school, and her minions. Please take that final word of the preceding sentence seriously. After my first meeting with the school’s head and said acolytes, I knew I was in trouble. In short, if you’re not willing to play the irrational games and buy into the very cult-like (not to mention very prudish) culture, you will soon find yourself on the outs. 

In addition, many of the top executive/managerial positions are held not by people experienced in business, administration or leadership, but failed actors, dancers and musicians who are AMDA alumni. You might be an experienced professional with over 20 years in the field of business management, for example, but find a 30 year-old ex-dancer supervising and micromanaging your every move. The head of the school is rarely there, and when she is, she’ll swoop in and demand irrational things that undermine all the work you’ve put in. She also demonstrates no actual ability as a leader or administrator and is shockingly prudish, more akin to a middle school librarian from the Midwest than head of progressive-minded performing arts school. As a result, people avoid her and most of the people in upper management like the plague, resulting in a complete communication breakdown among the levels of leadership, which makes it impossible to get anything substantive done. 

After a month on the job, during which time I not only completed all the work they said they needed done during the fall semester (with only stellar feedback on my performance, I might add), I was let go, with no explanation, other than “It’s not working out.” I’ll add that I was called into HR to receive my walking papers twenty minutes after filing my last project. 

Later, I was told by several of my former colleagues that this was actually a contract gig, as opposed to a full-time position, and this is AMDA’s usual M.O.: they hire a seasoned professional to whom they assign the jobs that require heavy lifting, then let them go once that’s done, so the people who are lower on the ladder can dot the I’s and cross the t’s, thus saving them money. Apparently in both their NY and LA locations, they've earned the nickname SCAMDA, in spades, due to this and other things.

On the positive side, I met some nice people while I was there, all of whom seemed like they’d had all the life and stuffing knocked out of them by the oppressive culture that AMDA submerges you in. I hope they’re all able to move onto greener pastures. 

In short, if you’re someone who’s “go with the flow,” and know how to adapt yourself to any environment, who can “be who others want you to be,” this might actually be a good fit for you. If, however, you’re a strong, type-A personality who’s used to having a degree of autonomy both personally and professionally, speaking your mind, and not having to knuckle under to “superiors” who, quite frankly, if it weren’t for the title by their names, not only wouldn’t be your superiors, but would most likely be serving you coffee somewhere, AVOID AMDA AT ALL COSTS.
